body.p:
Covington March 21th 1864
To His Excelency T. E. Bramblett Gov of Kentucky

Your Petitioner J. H. Condell would respectfully represent that he is Deputy Sheriff for H F Bowen. Sheriff of Kenton County K.y. That at the December term of the Kenton County Circuit Court 1863. A Judgement was rendered against one Iseah McKnight for the sum of Sixty dollars, and a capias was issued for the arrest of the said McKnight who evaded the officers from time to time, as he lived some distance from the city of Covington near the Ohio River. After repeated attempts to Make the arrest as it was my duty to do ^and in conformity with instructions of Comth Attorney^ about the 1th of December last John S. Scott also a Deputy Sheriff and your petitioner watched his house all night but without success, the next night your petitioner ^alone^ watched all night and about 6 Oclock in the morning discovered McKnight approaching within a short distance of him. your petitioner then commanded him stand, but he would not surrender himself and ran for the Ohio River where a Boat was in waiting to take him to the State of Ohio. Your petitioner still commanded him to stop, that if he would not, your petitioner would shoot him. He continued to run, when your petitioner fired three pistol shots, but had no intention of wounding him, but expected so to alarm him that he would surrender himself and become ameanable to the order of the order of the Court. He still continued to run and finally escaped to the state of Ohio
over

At the present March term 1864 of the Kenton Circuit Court at Covington your Petitioner was endited for "Shooting with intent to Kill" the said McKnight and was fined $2500 Your petitioner has thus briefly stated the facts as the occured, he believeing that he was only using necessary force to make the arrest. Your Petitioner would therefore pray your Excelency to remit said fine and in duty bound will ever pray

I was atty for J. H. Coudell in the above recited case. I think he has stated ^the^ case, about as strong against himself as it was made by the proof. In addition thereto, it affords me pleasure to say he is a worthy and accommading & efficient officer. At the time of the shooting he was not experienced in the duties & liabilities of his office, I am satisfied he only desires to do his duty.

I am sir
S M Moore

We of the Jury who tried the case vs J H Caudell, unite
with him in the request that the fine be remited,

F Dorman
James Riddle
John Stephen
John M Ferguson
U. Shinkle
Elijah Yates
E. G. Clarkson foreman Jury
Henry Wenzel
W. J. Hyde
Thomas Rosborn
J. W. Neal
John Baldwin
We also recommend the foregoing petition of J H Caudell to the most favorable consideration by His Excellency, The Governor

From the information which I have obtained in relation to the above case of Mr Condell I have no doubt that justice would be promoted by relieving him of the fine. he is poor and cannot well pay the fine & costs, which are quite as much as the fine, and he is an effective and conscientious officer, and such a man as in needed here- I would be gratified if the fine Would be remitted --

Very Truly Your Excelency
obt Sevt
M M Barber

Kenton Cr Ct
vs
J. H. Condell
$25 --
Remit except fees & costs
Tho E Bramlette
9th Apl/64
